Efficient fixation of CO2 with epoxides catalyzed by Mg(II)-N4 complexes Chunnian Xia Writing – review & editing Supervision a ⁎ Xinyi Wu Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Conceptualization a Bingyang Wang Writing – review & editing Conceptualization b Han Zhang Conceptualization a Kailin Chen Investigation Conceptualization a Nuoqi Jin Conceptualization a Qiangsheng Sun Investigation Formal analysis b Wei Sun Writing – review & editing Supervision b ⁎ a College of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310014, PR China College of Pharmaceutical Sciences Zhejiang University of Technology Hangzhou 310014 PR China aCollege of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310014, PR China b State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and CO2 Utilization, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, PR China State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and CO2 Utilization Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Lanzhou 730000 PR China bState Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and CO2 Utilization, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. In this study, a series of Mg(II) complexes supported by aminopyridine-N4 (MEP, DAP, TPA) and TMC (14-TMC) ligands were synthesized and characterized using various spectroscopic techniques. These Mg(II) complexes were investigated the catalytic activity for the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide with epoxides to obtain cyclic carbonates under cocatalyst- and solvent-free conditions, providing moderate to excellent yields depending on the specific N4 ligands used. The study involved analyzing the spectroscopic characterizations and experimental results to discuss the possible ligand topological structures of Mg-N4 complexes and their impact on catalytic performance. Moreover, the addition of (triphenylphosphoranylidene)ammonium chloride (PPNCl) as a cocatalyst significantly enhanced the turnover frequency (TOF) to 2100 h-1 for the Mg-1 [MEP-Mg(II), 0.01 mol % catalyst loading]. Also, the Mg-1 catalyst demonstrates excellent stability under the reaction conditions, allowing for multiple reuses. Graphical abstract A series of Mg(II) complexes of N4 (MEP, DAP, TPA, and 14-TMC) ligands were synthesized. These Mg(II) complexes demonstrated good catalytic activity for the coupling reaction of CO2 with epoxides in the absence/presence of cocatalyst (such as, PPNCl). The possible ligand topological structures of Mg-N4 complexes were discussed based on the 1H NMR spectra and crystal structure. Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 conversion Mg(II) N4 complexe Cyclic carbonates Epoxides Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide, a byproduct of fossil fuel combustion, is a major greenhouse gas that significantly contributes to environmental challenges. Hence, controlling CO2 concentration in the atmosphere is a worldwide issue, and carbon dioxide capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS) has garnered significant attention [1–3]. Additionally, it is a non-toxic and abundant resource that holds promise as a renewable carbon feedstock [4–6]. In light of sustainable development and the principles of green chemistry, the conversion of CO2 into high-value-added chemicals not only aids in reducing carbon emissions but also yields valuable products [7–9]. Over the past few decades, researchers have developed various catalytic systems aimed at converting CO2 into essential chemical feedstocks and fuels [10–15]. Among these transformations, the coupling reaction of CO2 with epoxides to produce five-membered cyclic carbonates is noteworthy due to its high atom economy [16–18]. In addition, these five-membered cyclic carbonates serve not only as important intermediates in biodegradable polymers [19,20] and pharmaceuticals [21–23] but also as polar aprotic solvents [24] and electrolytes in lithium-ion batteries [25,26]. To date, a diverse array of functionalized catalysts has been successfully developed for synthesizing cyclic carbonates from epoxides and carbon dioxide [27]. These catalysts include quaternary ammonium salts [28,29], ionic liquids [30–33], metal-based catalysts [34–37], and so on. Based on these reports, an efficient catalytic system typically features a Lewis acid center to activate the epoxide and a nucleophilic site for the epoxide ring-opening step [38–40]. Among the well-established binary/bifunctional catalytic systems (e.g., quaternary ammonium salts, ionic liquids, metal complexes), biomimetic metalloporphyrin complexes (such as those containing Co, Zn, Al, and Mg) have been extensively studied for the catalytic fixation of CO2 with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates [41–45]. Notably, magnesium is abundant, biocompatible, and plays a crucial role in biological processes, making it an ideal candidate for sustainable catalytic systems that lower environmental impact and advance green chemistry. In 2012, Jing and coworkers examined several metal porphyrin complexes, including Al, Mg, and Sn, for the coupling reaction of CO2 with epoxides. Notably, Mg(TPP) (TPP is tetraphenylporphyrin) combined with tetra-n-butylammonium iodide has been identified as an effective binary catalytic system for cyclic carbonate synthesis (Fig. 1 a) [42]. Furthermore, Ema and colleagues reported the development of a highly active bifunctional di- and tri-porphyrin catalyst with multiple nucleophilic active sites on its side chains. The Mg complex achieved impressive turnover numbers (TON) and turnover frequencies (TOF) of 220,000 and 46,000 h-1, respectively (Fig. 1b) [46]. Ding and coworkers presented a magnesium-based catalyst (Mg-por/pho@POP) that integrates porphyrin and phosphonium salt within a porous organic polymer, enabling efficient production of cyclic carbonates from epoxides and CO2 at mild conditions, even at room temperature (Fig. 1c) [47]. Also, Gruttadauria, Aprile, Giacalone, and coworkers reported bifunctional magnesium porphyrin-imidazolium bromide polymer (TSP-Mg-imi) for the coupling of CO2 with epoxides, giving TON of 24,700 [48]. Very recently, they demonstrated that the imidazolium bromide substituted magnesium phthalocyanine polymers as efficient bifunctional catalysts for the coupling of CO2 with epoxides with TON of 5950 [49]. Similarly, tetradentate nitrogen ligands (N4), which mimic non-heme enzymes, are highly versatile and easy to synthesize [50–53]. Recently, Cho and co-workers reported C 3-symmertric zinc complexes of tripodal tren-based ligands for transforming CO2 into cyclic carbonates without any cocatalysts [54]. Also, we developed a series of bifunctional zinc(II) and cobalt(II)-N4 complexes that demonstrate effective catalytic performance in the reaction of carbon dioxide with epoxides [55,56]. Interestingly, single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of the Zn complexes revealed two distinct coordination modes. One of these is N3 coordination mode, which facilitates the release of a pyridine group capable of activating CO2 [56]. Given the diverse coordination modes of N4 ligands and the potential geometric structures of the resulting metal complexes, we are very interested in expanding their catalytic applications. In this work, we report the synthesis of magnesium (II) complexes with linear aminopyridine N4 ligands, as well as magnesium (II) complexes with TPA (a tripodal N4 ligand, TPA = tris(2-pyridylmethyl)amine) and 14-TMC (a macrocyclic N4 ligand, 14-TMC = N,N',N'',N'''-tetramethyl-1,4,8,11- tetraazacyclotetradecane). We demonstrate that these magnesium (II) complexes act as single-component catalysts, exhibiting good to excellent catalytic activity in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides (Fig. 2). The supporting ligands play a crucial role in regulating the catalytic activity. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of Mg(ii) complexes The linear aminopyridine (MEP = N,N'-dimethyl-N,N'-bis(2-pyridylmethyl) −1,2-ethanediamine; The magnesium(II) complexes Mg-1–5 could be readily synthesized by the reaction of MgBr2 with the corresponding N4 ligands [N, N'-dimethyl-N, N'-bis(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,2-ethylenediamine (MEP) [57], N, N'-bis((4-(dimethylamino)- pyridin-2-yl)methyl)-N,N'-di-methylethane-1,2-ethylene-diamine (Me2NMEP) [56], 1,4-bis(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-diazacycl-oheptane (DAP) [55], TPA and 14-TMC] in excellent yields. In general, linear tetradentate N4 ligands can coordinate to octahedral metal centers in three possible topologies, including cis-α, cis-β, and trans [58–61]. As previously reported, 1H NMR spectroscopy can provide direct evidence for identifying the possible geometric isomers of these complexes [55,58]. Each geometric isomer produces characteristic chemical shift patterns for the α-H atoms of pyridine. For instance, the α-H atoms of pyridines in the cis-β isomer are unequal, resulting in two peaks in the 1H NMR. The 1H NMR spectrum of the Mg-1 (MEP-Mg(H2O)2Br2) complex displayed seven peaks in the aromatic region (Fig. 3 b). In contrast, the spectrum of the MEP ligand (Fig. 3a), which shows only four peaks between 7–8 ppm, suggests that the Mg-1 complex likely contains two sets of peaks corresponding to two isomers. Given the number of peaks, both isomers should be C2-symmetric structure, indicating the presence of cis-α and trans isomers, as a C1-symmetric structure would show more peaks. Subsequently, one of the isomer of Mg-1 was identified as the cis-α topology by single crystal X-ray crystallography diffraction (Fig. 4 ). In this structure, two pyridine rings are coordinated to the metal center in a trans relationship, with the N-methyl groups positioned opposite each other. The structure of Mg-1 also demonstrates that both water molecules are coordinated to the Mg(II) center rather than bromide ions. This may be due to the presence of trace amount of water in the solvents during the process for growth crystals. In this structure, both bromide ions are counter anions, thus indicating that the bromide ions in Mg-1 can more readily serve as nucleophiles in the coupling of CO2 with epoxides. Specifically, the 1H NMR spectrum of the Mg-2 (Me2NMEP-MgBr2) complex with Me2NMEP ligand shows one peak at 8.18 ppm (Fig. 3c and d), corresponding to the α-H of the pyridine, suggesting that the complex shows a stable configuration consistent with the cis-α topology. Similarly, the 1H NMR spectra of the Mg-3 (DAP-MgBr2), Mg-4 (TPA-MgBr2) and Mg-5 (14-TMC-MgBr2) reveal that these complexes are obtained as single topological structure. 2.2 Evaluation of catalytic activity Using epichlorohydrin 1a as a model substrate, we initially investigated the catalytic performance of magnesium complexes Mg-1–5 under cocatalyst- and solvent-free conditions at 80 °C and 10 bar of CO2. We found that these magnesium complexes could catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of epichlorohydrin 1a and CO2 to yield corresponding cyclic carbonate 2a with yields ranging from 58 % to 98 % at a 1a/ catalyst ratio of 1/100 (Table 1 , entries 1 − 5). When employing Mg-1, 2a was obtained in 88 % yield under the same conditions (Table 1, entry 1). As expected, the complex Mg-2 exhibited the highest catalytic activity, resulting in a 98 % yield of cyclic carbonate 2a (Table 1, entry 2). This impressive performance of Mg-2 is likely attributed to the -NMe2 groups on the both pyridine rings, which can directly activate CO2. The Mg-3 complex, featuring a 1,4-diazacycloheptane skeleton, was also examined; it demonstrated lower activity compared to Mg-1 and Mg-2, potentially due to steric hindrance within its structure (Table 1, entry 3). To further explore the impact of structural variations on catalytic performance, Mg-4 complex containing a tripodal TPA ligand and Mg-5 with macrocyclic 14-TMC ligand were studied (Table 1, entries 4–5). Compared to the complexes Mg-1–3, Mg-4 resulted in a lowest yield of 58 % (Table 1, entry 4), while Mg-5, Mg(II)-14-TMC, produced comparable result to that of Mg-3 (Table 1, entries 3 and 5). Given the ease preparation of Mg-1, and its comparable catalytic performance to Mg-2, we then focused on optimizing the reaction conditions using the Mg-1 complex, including temperature, time, and catalyst loading. Increasing the temperature to 100 °C achieved complete conversion of epichlorohydrin, and a 99 % yield of product 2a was observed (Table 1, entry 8). However, further investigations into reducing the reaction time at 100 °C resulted in a significant decrease in activity (Table 1, entry 9). We also optimized the process by testing different catalyst loadings while maintaining constant reaction temperature and CO2 pressure. To our delight, a catalyst loading of 0.5 mol % could maintain the quantitative conversion of the substrate (Table 1, entry 10). However, reducing the catalyst loading to 0.1 mol % resulted in only a 50 % yield (Table 1, entry 11). It is known that commonly used cocatalysts, such as tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) and (triphenylphosphoranylidene) ammonium chloride (PPNCl), can significantly influence catalytic activity [43,56]. As expected, the addition of cocatalyst, even with a 0.1 mol % catalyst loading of Mg-1, led to a yield of 97 % (Table 1, entries 13 and 14). Remarkably, using an extremely low catalytic loading of 0.01 mol % Mg-1 combined with PPNCl as a cocatalyst, we achieved a turnover frequency (TOF) of 2100 h−1 at 120 °C (Table 1, entries 15 and 16). The synergistic effect between Mg-1 and PPNCl leads to an enhancement on the catalytic activity [62]. To explore the potential and general applicability of the Mg-N4 complexes, the coupling reaction of CO2 with a variety of mono-substituted epoxides were investigated under the optimized conditions (Table 2 ). The scope of epoxides included aliphatic, aromatic, ether-substitution, halogenated, and olefinic groups. The halogen-containing carbonates 2a and 2b, from the substrates 1a and 1b, were isolated in excellent yields. Propylene oxide 1c and epoxide 1e were converted into the target products with good yields (Table 2, 2c, 82 %; 2e, 82 %). However, some epoxides, such as styrene oxide, did not yield satisfactory yield at 100 °C. Based on previous studies, increasing the reaction temperature could enhance substrate conversion [55]. Consequently, we elevated the temperature to 120 °C for epoxides containing phenyl and alkyl groups, as well as a series of glycidyl ethers. This adjustment was particularly beneficial for the challenging styrene oxide 1d, increasing the yield of the cyclic carbonate to 70 % (Table 2, 2d). Additionally, epoxides 1e-i, bearing various ether substitutions, could be well converted into cyclic carbonate 2e-i in ranging from 74 % to 96 %. Due to the inherently lower reactivity of alkyl-substituted epoxides, in the case of epoxide 1k, switching to catalyst Mg-2 resulted in an excellent yield of 96 % for 2k at 120 °C. Furthermore, at increased reaction time and with Mg-2 as the catalyst, two functionalized di-epoxides, 1l and 1m, were smoothly transformed into their corresponding products with excellent yields (2l, 98 % yield; 2m, 92 % yield). The cycloaddition of CO2 with more challenging cyclohexene oxide was also performed with Mg-2 as catalyst, it provided the desired cis-cyclic carbonate 2n in 67 % yield at 120 °C for 24 h. Further, the yield of cis-cyclic carbonate 2n could be improved to 87 % when using 0.5 mol % PPNCl as cocatalyst [63,64]. These results demonstrate that the Mg-N4 complexes, particularly Mg-2, are efficient one-component catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and a wide range of epoxides. 2.3 Reusability of Mg(ii)-N4 catalyst To further test the stability of the Mg-1 complex, its recyclability was assessed in the coupling reaction of CO2 with epichlorohydrin 1a under standard conditions. Given the good solubility of Mg-1 in cyclic carbonate 2a, fresh epichlorohydrin was directly added to the reaction vessel for the subsequent run after the each reaction [65]. The Mg-1 complex could be reused five times, and a slight decline in activity after each cycle was observed, largely due to the gradually reduced catalyst concentration (Fig. 5 ). Furthermore, the catalyst could be recovered from the product via vacuum distillation. Thus, this method shows inherent limitation for the synthesis of high-boiling-point cyclic carbonates due to the soluble nature of Mg-N4 complex. Based on the 1H NMR spectra, the recycled catalyst was nearly identical to the fresh catalyst, thereby indicating that the Mg-1 complex is stable enough during the catalytic reaction. 2.4 Reaction mechanism After investigating the performance of these Mg(II) complexes in the coupling of CO2 with epoxides, we are interesting in understanding how the N4 ligand affects the catalytic activity. It is well-known that the Lewis acidity of the metal center can modulate the activation of the epoxide; increased Lewis acidity facilitates the ring-opening of epoxide by a nucleophilic halide anion more easily [66]. The trend in the Lewis acidity of complexes Mg-1, Mg-2 has been qualitatively evaluated by a 31P NMR chemical downfield shift compared to free Et3PO (Fig. S1, 13.03 ppm for Mg-1, 13.13 ppm for Mg-2.) [67,68], Mg-2 exhibits higher Lewis acidity, aligning well with the catalytic activities of complexes Mg-1, and Mg-2 (Table 1, entries 1 and 2). Also, comparison of the chemical downfield shifts of analogues of Zn-N4 complexes [55] and Co-N4 complexes [56] indicates that Mg-N4 complexes demonstrate higher Lewis acidity (see the Supporting Information, Fig. S1). As shown in the crystal structure of complex Mg-1 (Fig. 4), Br- anions can readily dissociate from the magnesium(II) complex, acting as nucleophiles for breaking the epoxide ring [55,63]. Based on previous reports and these above observations [39,46,64,66], we propose a mechanism for the magnesium(II)-catalyzed coupling reaction of CO2 with epoxides, illustrated in Fig. 6 . The catalytic cycle begins with the activation of the epoxide by the Mg(II) complex, and the bromide anion facilitates the ring-opening of epoxide, generating the alkoxide intermediate C. This intermediate then reacts with CO2 to produce carbonate species D. Finally, the desired cyclic carbonates are released after an intramolecular nucleophilic attack of species D. 3 Conclusions In conclusion, we synthesized a series of Mg-N4 complexes including linear N4 ligands, tripodal TPA ligand, and 14-TMC ligand. These Mg complexes proved to be effective catalysts, especially, Mg-1 (MEP-MgBr2) and Mg-2 (Me2NMEP-MgBr2), for the coupling reaction of CO2 with epoxides under solvent- and cocatalyst-free conditions. In combination with TBAB or PPNCl, the magnesium(II) complexes demonstrated higher catalytic activity for this reaction (catalyst loading as low as 0.01 mol %), and TOF of 2100 h-1 was abserved. Additionally, the Mg(II) complexes could be reused five times only with a slight decrease in catalytic activity due to the gradually reduced catalyst concentration. On the basis of the results, the topological structures of the Mg(II) complexes play a crucial role for controlling the reactivity. Future studies will continue to understand the structure-activity relationship of this type of metal-N4 complexes. coredata.dc:description: In this study, a series of Mg(II) complexes supported by aminopyridine-N4 (MEP, DAP, TPA) and TMC (14-TMC) ligands were synthesized and characterized using various spectroscopic techniques. These Mg(II) complexes were investigated the catalytic activity for the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide with epoxides to obtain cyclic carbonates under cocatalyst- and solvent-free conditions, providing moderate to excellent yields depending on the specific N4 ligands used. The study involved analyzing the spectroscopic characterizations and experimental results to discuss the possible ligand topological structures of Mg-N4 complexes and their impact on catalytic performance. Moreover, the addition of (triphenylphosphoranylidene)ammonium chloride (PPNCl) as a cocatalyst significantly enhanced the turnover frequency (TOF) to 2100 h-1 for the Mg-1 [MEP-Mg(II), 0.01 mol % catalyst loading]. Also, the Mg-1 catalyst demonstrates excellent stability under the reaction conditions, allowing for multiple reuses.

coredata.dc:title: Efficient fixation of CO2 with epoxides catalyzed by Mg(II)-N4 complexes
